body:
Only pull requests, merges to master, and branches starting with the prefix "test" will trigger Travis CI builds.

/cc @vors @lzybkr @lilyfang @JamesWTruher 

I would still like to explore speeding up the build by:
- tagging many more tests as slow
- running OS X builds only for merges to master

As it is, our builds take about 18 minutes on Linux, and 22 on OS X. The majority of the time is spent waiting for the queue to free up, and once building, spent running Pester tests.
title: Whitelist master and test branches for Travis CI

If it is a bug report:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

On Windows

```
PS> throw ("1234567890"*([Console]::BufferWidth/10 + 10))
```

then with the mouse, select the text of the error message, paste on something like notepad

no unnecessary line breaks
## Actual behavior

line breaks at the buffer width
## Environment data

Win10 any version

body:
Updating Test-RunningAsElevated to return true on *nix and OS X. 

Permission models on *nix can be very complex, to the point that you
could never possibly guess without simply trying what you need to try;
This is totally different from Windows where you can know what you can
or cannot do with/without admin rights.
title: Updating Test-RunningAsElevated to return true on *nix and OS X.

```
Darwin osdev-mac1011-01 15.5.0 Darwin Kernel Version 15.5.0: Tue Apr 19 18:36:36 PDT 2016; root:xnu-3248.50.21~8/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64
```

body:
Hey, I am from the Hyper-V team and we have some cmdlets that were working on for [Docker](https://github.com/Microsoft/Docker-PowerShell). All of the binaries are built using dotnet cli and are .NET Core compatible except for the PS Module classes because the only released reference to SMA are net46 and lower. I would like to try and port the cmdlets to run in PowerShell so we can give them a shot on Linux but need the set of binaries to be available to link in at build time for the PS module. Do you guys maintain a MyGet or VSO feed that I can pull the binaries from?

@swernli FYI
title: Is there a private MyGet feed for building binary PS modules?

body:
<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Context

On Linux, it's common to use error stream (2) as an information stream.
There is no errors in this case, it's just a way to report info.
When PowerShell redirects error stream, it wraps all output from stream 2 in **NativeCommandError** ErrorRecord.

That doesn't happen for interactive experience (when there is no redirection), but it shows up in logs, scripting and non-console powershell hosts (i.e. PowerShell ISE).
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
grep 2>txt
cat txt
```

On windows, you can use grep that comes with git to do the same.
## Expected behavior

```
Usage: /usr/bin/grep [OPTION]... PATTERN [FILE]...
Try '/usr/bin/grep --help' for more information.
```
## Actual behavior

```
grep : Usage: /usr/bin/grep [OPTION]... PATTERN [FILE]...
At line:1 char:1
+ grep 2>txt
+ ~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (Usage: /usr/bin...TTERN [FILE]...:String) [], RemoteException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NativeCommandError

Try '/usr/bin/grep --help' for more information.
```
## Environment data

Any version of powershell

labels.description: (LEGACY) Helps filter issues that might be higher priority because they directly affect usability
labels.name: Usability

title: Error stream and ErrorRecords

title: Rename Desktop & Core PSEditions to WindowsPowerShell & PowerShellCore

body:
**What is the issue?**
$PSVersionTable.PSEdition currently supports Desktop and Core enums. Because PowerShell is going to be Open and also available on Linux/Mac from August, we decided to rename these values so as to make it clear to the end user.
We decided to use the names WindowsPowerShell,PowerShellCore.

**How was the issue/bug found?**
Internal brainstorming w.r.t PowerShell efforts.

**What is the user/product impact?**
Long term using the words like "Desktop" confuses customers. We would like customers to be aware of 2 kinds of PowerShell -WindowsPowerShell and PowerShellCore. The word "Desktop" does not align with our long term direction.
title: Rename Desktop & Core PSEdition values to WindowsPowerShell & PowerShellCore

body:
From the link @ https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/building/linux.md, supposedly the developers should be able to build powershell from the source code. Recently, I tried it out, and found the below issues, 
1. For "Environment" section, it should be clear to the developers that the current instruction actually only works for Ubuntu 14.04 LTS, for other newer version, dev will hit the below errors due to the missing binaries,  

Reading state information... Done
Package libicu52 is not available, but is referred to by another package.
This may mean that the package is missing, has been obsoleted, or
is only available from another source

E: Package 'libicu52' has no installation candidate
(Reading database ... 59652 files and directories currently installed.)
Preparing to unpack ./powershell_0.6.0-1_amd64.deb ...
Unpacking powershell (0.6.0-1) over (0.6.0-1) ...
dpkg: dependency problems prevent configuration of powershell:
powershell depends on libunwind8; however:
  Package libunwind8 is not installed.
powershell depends on libicu52; however:
  Package libicu52 is not installed.

dpkg: error processing package powershell (--install):
dependency problems - leaving unconfigured
Errors were encountered while processing:
powershell
1. For "Working with PowerShell repository" section, 
   a. In git clone command, It will be nice to let developers know that if they use the two-factor authentication for their git hub acount, they need to use access token as password, instead of their normal passwords when the authentication is prompted for git clone. It could be obvious, but it would be helpful to remind. 
   b. If they don't add --recursive in git clone, or there is some error during --recursive git clone. They need to clone the submodules manually. They need to cd to PowerShell directory first, then run the below two commands, 
   git submodule init
   git submodule update

Please make sure installing all the submodules successfully, else, building using Start-PSBuild later will fail. 
1. For "Toolchain Setup" section, the below bash commands do not work, 

"GITHUB_TOKEN=<replace with your token>
./tools/download.sh"

You need to call "export GITHUB_TOKEN=<replace with your token>" first, then "./tools/download.sh"
title: [Doc Bug] - Building PowerShell Linux Instruction

body:
## Steps to reproduce

Start-PSBuild
## Expected behavior

works
## Actual behavior

mc.exe not found. Install Microsoft Windows SDK.
At C:\git\PowerShell\Build.psm1:104 char:13
-             throw 'mc.exe not found. Install Microsoft Windows SDK.'
-             ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  - CategoryInfo          : OperationStopped: (mc.exe not foun...ft Windows SDK.:String) [], RuntimeException
  - FullyQualifiedErrorId : mc.exe not found. Install Microsoft Windows SDK.

This message isn't helpful. What version of Windows SDK is required?
Code performs recurse search in C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Windows , however on my machine I have v7.0A, v8.1, v8.1A, v10.0A and none of those contains mc.exe

It would be useful if error message at least provided link to exact version of SDK which is required and ideally it would be installed by Start-PSBootstrap.
## Environment data

Name                           Value

---

PSVersion                      5.1.14392.1000
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.14392.1000
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
title: mc.exe required

I need to finalize the solution for compiling binaries against our desired OS matrix and how we want to deal with VS redistribution.

Questions to resolve:
1. Do we want to depend on a shared VS redistributable environment on the system (installed via vcredist.exe)?
2. Do we want to statically link VS libraries into our native binaries?
3. Which technique works better on downlevel SKUs?

<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

submit a PR to master with no changes
## Expected behavior

tests should pass
## Actual behavior

tests fail
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/PowerShell/powershell/build/0.6.0.3462
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable

```

title: BLOCKING: tests in master are broken

body:
<!-- PR checklist -->
- [ X] Resolves issue #xyz.
- [ X] Code is up-to-date with `master`.
- [ X] Add tests that fail without your changes.
- [ ] Update all relevant [documentation](../docs).

<!-- Provide more details about the PR below -->

These changes rely on some new Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure (MMI) and Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.Native (MMIN) nuget packages.  The packages and this changeset will need to in together, or the build will break due to MMI having some internal types name changed.  

The newly added Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimCmdlets sources have two files which reference some MMI internal types, and those will need to be fixed at some point when we have the entirety of MMI working. For now, I've commented out the relevant references (in two files: ExportBinaryMiLogCommand.cs and ImportBinaryMiLogCommand.cs).

The new end-to-end tests of DSC MOF compilation from a configuration block will work when the new MMI and MMIN nuget packages are available on the nuget package server. I am not familiar with how one would go about publishing those, and I would like assistance from someone who is more familiar with it than I am!
title: Enabling DSC MOF compilation on Linux

body:
PowerShell needs a plan for the public preview release, covering the following:
- [x] "official" packages (created on build systems to avoid paths like `/home/andrew/src` in debug info)
  - [x] DEB package for Ubuntu 14.04 and **16.04** #1433
  - [x] RPM package for CentOS 7 and **RHEL** #1434
  - [x] PKG for OS X (maybe DMG)
  - [x] MSI / AppX for each targeted Windows platform
  - [ ] Source packages
  - [x] Signed packages (?)
- [x] Finalized EULA/License/copyright/description/maintainer etc. #1037, #1422
- [x] Finalized *nix package names and layout #1309
- [x] Correct version info #1369, #1084
- [x] Remove Windows branding #1033 
- [x] Remove useless URLs
- [ ] #1160: Remove secrets
- [ ] #1553: Re-create CI projects to make them visible

<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
Set-PSReadlineKeyHandler -Key '"' -Function SelfInsert
```
## Expected behavior

It works
## Actual behavior

`Set-PSReadlineKeyHandler : Unable to load DLL 'user32.dll': The specified module could not be found`
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0
PSEdition                      Linux
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v0.6.0
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              1.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

```
title: PSReadline custom key binding doesn't always work on Linux

body:
when converting file [TestGetCommand.cs](https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-monad/blob/source-depot/monad/tests/monad/src/engine/core/TestGetCommand.cs) in line 849, function 'TestGetCommand-DynamicParametersDCR':

```
function TestGetCommand-DynamicParametersDCR 
{
[CmdletBinding()]
    param (
    [Parameter(Mandatory = $true, Position = 0)]
    [ValidateSet("ReturnNull", "ReturnThis", "Return1", "Return2","Return3", "ReturnDuplicateParameter", "ReturnAlias", "ReturnDuplicateAlias","ReturnObjectNoParameters", "ReturnGenericParameter", "ThrowException")]
    [string] $TestToRun,

    [Parameter()]
    [Type]$ParameterType
    )

    DynamicParam {
        if ( ! $testToRun ) {
            $testToRun = $defaultAction
        }
        $dynamicParamDictionary = [System.Management.Automation.RuntimeDefinedParameterDictionary]::new()
        switch ( $testToRun )
        {                   
            "returngenericparameter" {
                Write-Host "type is: $ParameterType"
                $attr1 = [System.Management.Automation.ParameterAttribute]::new()
                $attr1.ParameterSetName = "__AllParameterSets"
                $ac1 = [Collections.ObjectModel.Collection[Attribute]]::new()
                $ac1.Add($attr1)
                $p1 = [System.Management.Automation.RuntimeDefinedParameter]::new("TypedValue",$ParameterType,$ac1)                       
                $dynamicParamDictionary.Add("TypedValue",$p1)              
                break                         
            }
            default { 
                throw ([invalidoperationexception]::new("unable to determine which dynamic parameters to return!"))
                break
            }
        }
        return $dynamicParamDictionary
    }

    BEGIN {
        $ReturnNull = "ReturnNull"
        $ReturnThis = "ReturnThis"
        $ReturnAlias = "ReturnAlias"
        $ReturnDuplicateAlias = "ReturnDuplicateAlias"
        $Return1 = "Return1"
        $Return2 = "Return2"
        $Return3 = "Return3"
        $ReturnDuplicateParameter = "ReturnDuplicateParameter"
        $ReturnObjectNoParameters = "ReturnObjectNoParameters"
        $ReturnGenericParameter = "ReturnGenericParameter"
        $ThrowException = "ThrowException"
        $DefaultAction = "returnnull"
        return $dynamicParamDictionary
    }
}
```

Run command:

```
$res1 = Get-Command testgetcommand-dynamicparametersdcr -ParameterType System.Diagnostics.Process -TestToRun ReturnGenericParameter 

$res2 = Get-command testgetcommand-dynamicparametersdcr -args '-testtorun','returngenericparameter','-parametertype','System.Diagnostics.Process'
```

**$ParameterType returns null when run the first command**, but for the second, it returns the correct value 'System.Diagnostics.Process'

This turns on the XML documentation generation for the Core PowerShell projects.

This does _not_ include the following:
- `docs/cmdlet-example/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.ArchiverProviders/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.CoreProviders/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.MetaProvider.PowerShell/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.MsiProvider/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.MsuProvider/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.NuGetProvider/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement.PackageSourceListProvider/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PackageManagement/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.PowerShell.PackageManagement/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.WSMan.Management.Activities/project.json`
- `src/TypeCatalogGen/project.json`
- `src/TypeCatalogParser/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimCmdlets/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.WSMan.Management/project.json`
- `src/Microsoft.WSMan.Runtime/project.json`
- `test/PSReadLine/project.json`
- `test/csharp/project.json`

@joeyaiello I know you were investigating this at some point, I think this is what you wanted.

body:
The debian package has certain fields such as License, Maintainer, Vendor etc that need to be reviewed and set correctly. This has to be done consistently for all *nix packages.

```
dpkg-query --status PowerShell

Package: powershell
Status: install ok installed
Priority: extra
Section: shells
Installed-Size: 73021
Maintainer: Andrew Schwartzmeyer <andschwa@microsoft.com>
Architecture: amd64
Version: 0.6.0-1
Depends: libunwind8, libicu52
Description: Open PowerShell on .NET Core
 PowerShell is an open-source, cross-platform, scripting language and rich object shell.
 Built upon .NET Core, it is also a C# REPL.
License: Unlicensed
Vendor: Microsoft <mageng@microsoft.com>
Build-Depends: dotnet, cmake, g++
Homepage: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell


```
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
Name                           Value                                           
----                           -----                                           
PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0                                     
PSEdition                      Linux                                           
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                         
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0                                         
GitCommitId                    v0.6.0                                          
CLRVersion                                                                     
WSManStackVersion              1.0                                             
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                             
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1  

```

body:
Due to #567, `rm` isn't an alias for Remove-Item, so the cleanup stage of the `Save-Package` tests fails (quietly) on Linux.

Just need to go replace `rm` with `Remove-Item`.

body:
## Steps to reproduce

Potentially a test issue. 
.\runlite -suite Scripting.CoreLanguage.CoreLanguageTest -pri  -test DefaultExecutionContextSessionStateLanguageModeInRemoteSession
## Expected behavior

The language mode is FullLanguage.
## Actual behavior

LanguageMode is 3. 

Exception calling "Invoke" with "0" argument(s): "Default $host.Runspace.InitialSessionState.LanguageMode should be FullLanguage when UMCI is not enabled.: '3' does not equal 'FullLanguage'
CallStack: Asserts.ps1: line 87 <- Asserts.ps1: line 219 <- Lite.Scripting.CoreLanguage.CoreLanguageTest.ps1: line 842"
System.Management.Automation.MethodInvocationException: Exception calling "Invoke" with "0" argument(s): "Default $host.Runspace.InitialSessionState.LanguageMode should be FullLanguage when UMCI is not enabled.: '3' does not equal 'FullLanguage'
CallStack: Asserts.ps1: line 87 <- Asserts.ps1: line 219 <- Lite.Scripting.CoreLanguage.CoreLanguageTest.ps1: line 842" ---> System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException: Default $host.Runspace.InitialSessionState.LanguageMode should be FullLanguage when UMCI is not enabled.: '3' does not equal 'FullLanguage'
CallStack: Asserts.ps1: line 87 <- Asserts.ps1: line 219 <- Lite.Scripting.CoreLanguage.CoreLanguageTest.ps1: line 842
   at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PipelineBase.Invoke(IEnumerable input)
   at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.Pipeline.Invoke()
   at CallSite.Target(Closure , CallSite , Object )
   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at System.Management.Automation.ExceptionHandlingOps.CheckActionPreference(FunctionContext funcContext, Exception exception)
   at ExecuteInRunspace(Closure , FunctionContext )
## Environment data

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
```

## Steps to reproduce

Run BVT/DRT Remoting/Infrastructure and Scripting/Debugging tests. WSManPluginShellSessionUnitTests fail with MethodAccessException and TypeLoadException.
## Expected behavior

Tests pass.
## Actual behavior

**System.TypeLoadException**: Method 'WSManPluginRegisterShutdownCallback' in type 'System.Management.Automation.Remoting.UnitTests.SavesErrorCodeWSManPluginFacade' from assembly 'TAEF.WSManPlugin.UnitTests, Version=3.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35' does not have an implementation.
   at System.Management.Automation.Remoting.UnitTests.WSManPluginEntryDelegatesUnitTests.NullInputIsNoOp()
[HRESULT: 0x80131604]. Test operation failed: 'NullInputIsNoOp'.

**System.MethodAccessException**: Attempt by method 'System.Management.Automation.Remoting.UnitTests.WSManPluginEntryDelegatesUnitTests.InitPluginAssignsWorkerPtrs()' to access method 'System.Management.Automation.Remoting.WSManPluginEntryDelegates+WSManPluginEntryDelegatesInternal..ctor()' failed.
   at System.Management.Automation.Remoting.UnitTests.WSManPluginEntryDelegatesUnitTests.InitPluginAssignsWorkerPtrs()
[HRESULT: 0x80131604]. Test operation failed: 'InitPluginAssignsWorkerPtrs'.
## Environment data

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value

PSEdition                      Desktop
```

body:
This should enable building via PR from forks.

This token has read-only access to download the installer packages, but
should nonetheless be revoked and replaced with a wget download when the
repository goes public.
title: Add GitHub token as insecure environment variable

body:
## Steps to reproduce

Convert-String on Windows PowerShell build from GitHub. 
## Expected behavior

Cmdlet is found.
## Actual behavior

Cmdlet not found.
## Environment data

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v0.6.0-112-g3276846c401e0c2132cc260f89752b121c81abde
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

```

labels.description: The issue is a duplicate.
labels.name: Resolution-Duplicate

labels.description: An issue affecting or exposed by tests that have not been open sourced
labels.name: BVT/DRT

title: Convert-String cmdlet is missing

title: Add remain part of Parser Pester Unit Test

body:
## Steps to reproduce

I try test global:func as below, it shows it not work as expect:

```
PS /workspace/PowerShell> function global:func { 'global' };
PS /workspace/PowerShell> function func { 'default' };
PS /workspace/PowerShell> global:func;
default
```
## Expected behavior

"global:func;"'s output should be global
## Actual behavior

"global:func;"'s output is default
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell

PS /root> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0
PSEdition                      Linux
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v0.5.0-73-g1476be8ecf907c105210ed3b22289872c0578593
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              1.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
PS /root>

```
title: global:func not work?
